title: Basal Cell Carcinoma
diagnosis_topic: Pearly, slow-growing skin lesion consistent with basal cell carcinoma
setup_script: A 60-year-old woman with fair skin presents with a 5-mm pearly papule with telangiectasia on the bridge of her nose. It has been present for one year and has slowly enlarged.

dynamic_flow.reply: Translucent nodule with rolled borders and central depression; no ulceration.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about sun exposure and risk factors
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient reports years of outdoor work without sunscreen.
Shows arborizing vessels typical of basal cell carcinoma.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs shave or punch biopsy
dynamic_flow.reply: Pathology confirms nodular basal cell carcinoma.
Options include surgical excision with 4 mm margins or Mohs micrographic surgery for cosmetic areas.
Preferred for lesions on the face to maximize tissue conservation and ensure clear margins.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident provides postoperative care instructions
dynamic_flow.reply: Wound care, suture removal and scar management discussed.
Recurrence is low after complete excision but higher with positive margins or certain subtypes.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident educates about sun protection
dynamic_flow.reply: Regular sunscreen use, protective clothing and avoidance of tanning beds.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident screens for other skin lesions
dynamic_flow.reply: Full skin exam performed to look for additional actinic damage or lesions.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident differentiates from squamous cell carcinoma and melanoma
dynamic_flow.reply: Emphasize differences in appearance and metastatic potential.

critical_decision_points: Recognition and biopsy of suspicious skin lesions
Selection of appropriate treatment modality (excision vs. Mohs)
Patient counseling on sun protection and surveillance
Understanding recurrence risk and histologic subtypes
Full skin examination to identify additional lesions
